overview: This subject will bring together knowledge of students about speech pathology practice, and apply this beyond the direct clinical encounter. Students will be supported to understand and design interventions that build capacity in communities, to support people with communication and swallowing disorders. They will learn about models of working that incorporate people and groups beyond the immediate client- for example, with families, other professionals, and other services. Diversity and cultural safety will be a large focus in this subject, and students will engage with self and peer reflection around the development of their own practice in this area. In particular, students will be supported to identify Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander perspectives and to understand their role in providing culturally secure and responsive speech pathology services that take into account different ways of knowing, being and doing.
intended learning outcomes: Design and evaluate appropriate speech pathology interventions for diverse communities, including working with carers, families and broader communities, working collaboratively with other professions, and working via distance (telehealth);
Reflect on their own knowledge, values, and experiences to identify personal learning goals relating to the development of cultural responsiveness, and strategies for achieving those goals;
Integrate knowledge of Indigenous Australian cultures, histories and contemporary contexts in relation to speech pathology practice and service provision.

necessary pre-requisite: Note: these can be taken concurrently (at the same time)

assessments.description: Clinical exam (simulated patient). 10 minutes (total). Hurdle requirement:. Students must pass clinical exam to pass the subject

Prescribed texts: There are no specifically prescribed or recommended texts for this subject.
